title: Ten Habits that will get you ahead of 99% of People
subtitle: Improve your life and get ahead of your peers in 10 simple steps

content.text: The concept of habits became extremely popular in the recent years, mostly due to the personal development wave brought up by the Gen Z culture.
Also, due to the books that appeared in the recent years, out of which, the most famous and a favorite of mine, Atomic Habits.

Mostly, all this movement is about is taking control of your life. People were living on autopilot for so long, adhering to standards imposed by society, doing what needed to be done, without keeping track on how they spend their time.
As mental health became something people took seriously, it was inevitable that we would go to the cause of these issues and analyze what we do with our lives, and that is tracking habits.

The huge talk about habits and attention spent on it, sparked a lot of analysis into high performers, celebrities, CEOs, entrepreneurs, investors and any personality that is even remotely famous or has a following.

Out of these podcasts, books and YouTube videos, there appeared a multitude of habits and routines that are not only unsustainable and unrealistic, but they might cause anxiety and strain on the body, which defies the purpose of having them in the first place.
So let me tell you something once and for all:

content.quote: You don‚Äôt have to wake up at 5am, if that doesn‚Äôt work for you

content.text: You don‚Äôt have to do anything. The one thing you have to do is listen to your mind and body, and choose from these habits only what works for you and brings you a certain benefit.

sections.title: The 10 habits that improved my life

content.text: What I planning to give you today is a list of the habits that I have personally picked from the thousands that are popular, implemented, tested and adjusted into my life.
The order is completely random. So let‚Äôs begin:
In my own personal development journey, I was working on multiple aspects of my life: fitness, relationships, nutrition. But I was always leaving sleep as something to tackle on down the road.
I was always choosing having fun, partying, watching Netflix, movies, going out, reading, instead of sleeping.

While being in a plateau with my gym goals and nutrition, I got a dog. As some of you might know, dogs go to sleep pretty early and don‚Äôt tend to sleep in. This forced me to leave parties earlier, prioritize sleep and go to bed earlier because I was woken up pretty early in the morning.
They key takeaways here are:

list.text: Go to bed relatively earlier and wake up earlier (follow the natural circadian rhythm of your body)
Sleep for 8 hours (at least 7, at most 9)
Wake up at the end of a sleep cycle. Sleep cycles usually take 90 minutes. So set your alarm at the end of a multiple of 90 minutes.
Keep your bedroom a bit cooler than the rest of your house
Keep your bedroom dark while you sleep

content.text: There are countless studies on the benefits of exercise on your body, both physically and mentally.
What I observed with my training was that it gave me a few valuable things:
My training / exercise routine includes 3 or 4 strength training sessions that are no longer than one hour, once a week boxing class / swimming laps and 10.000 steps a day.

A great suggestion here based on my trials as a busy individual and studies from other specialists such as Andrew Huberman, it‚Äôs best to have these sessions in the morning, before work. This will help keep your energy levels high, avoid the afternoon energy drop, avoid over-caffeinating, keep your motivation high for the day and improve your mood.
Whenever you have time to do it, make sure to include it within your habits.

sections.title: Don‚Äôt drink coffee for the first 1‚Äì2 hours after you wake up

content.text: Coffee is probably your favorite morning ritual, your go to energy source, and I am the same. Giving up coffee is just something I would not do ever.
However, over-caffeinating is a real thing and a detrimental one at that. To avoid needing another coffee at lunchtime or in the afternoon, drink your first one 1‚Äì2 hours after you wake up.
As Atomic Habits describes amazingly, each habit has a cue. Usually, waking up is our signal to go get coffee. To add or remove habits, you need to play around with the cues.

For example, I am using the waking up cue, to get dressed and go to the gym. After that, I come home and get ready for work. At 9:00 when I turn on my laptop, that‚Äôs my cue to drink my coffee. Usually I wake up at 7:00‚Äì7:30 so I have between 1 and 2 hours before my coffee.

title: 7 Things emotionally intelligent people DON‚ÄôT say

content.text: Emotional Intelligence is one of the most important power skills that every professional needs.
Emotionally intelligent people are aware of their strengths and weaknesses, open to feedback and collaboration, and capable of building rapport (= establishing a connection) with others.
What they DON‚ÄôT do is use the following 7 phrases.
1. You always / you never
For example: ‚ÄúYou always message me after work hours‚Äù or ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre never happy with my work no matter what I do‚Äù.

What‚Äôs wrong with this phrase? Emotionally intelligent people don‚Äôt point fingers when they point out issues. They focus on solving the problem and inspiring people to improve rather than launching personal attacks.
Instead, you could say:

content.quote: ‚ÄúI feel like my work is not meeting your expectations. Can you tell me what you‚Äôd like me to change so that we‚Äôre on the same wavelength?‚Äù

content.text: 2. Why are you so‚Ä¶?
For example: ‚ÄúWhy are you so uncooperative?‚Äù
This question provokes an even more negative response instead of de-escalating the issue.
It sounds like you‚Äôre blaming the person for being a certain way. This guarantees to put them on the defensive.
Instead, you could say:

content.quote: ‚ÄúHelp me understand your perspective.‚Äù or ‚ÄúWhy do you feel this way about my proposal?‚Äù

content.text: The idea is to get the person to share their perspective free of judgment so you can reach a consensus.
3. Whatever / Doesn‚Äôt matter
These can often sound plain disrespectful. For example:
I can share these files with you if you want.

content.quote: When used like that, these phrases demonstrate very poor empathy. What‚Äôs the alternative? Just don‚Äôt use them when you respond to suggestions or offers.

content.text: Use them only when you want to say that there is no wrong option or something is genuinely not important.
For example: It doesn‚Äôt really matter when we complete this task because we don‚Äôt have a strict deadline for it.
4. That‚Äôs how I‚Äôve always done it before
When you explain why you did something a certain way by saying ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs just how I‚Äôve always done it before‚Äù ‚Äî this makes you come across as an inflexible person who is not open to learning.
Instead, try saying:

content.quote: ‚ÄúDo you think there‚Äôs a more effective approach to doing this? I‚Äôd like to learn about it‚Äù

content.text: 5. I don‚Äôt have time for this

This phrase sounds very disrespectful. It‚Äôs like you‚Äôre saying that you‚Äôre busier than everyone else and more important than them, and that‚Äôs not the kind of attitude you want to have with your colleagues or clients.
Instead, say:

content.quote: ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt fit it into my schedule‚Äù or simply ‚ÄúWould you be able to take on this task? I would highly appreciate it‚Äù.

content.text: 6. I‚Äôll try
This phrase often shows a lack of commitment and motivation. More often than not it means ‚ÄúI want to end this conversation and NOT do the thing you want me to do‚Äù.
Remember that it‚Äôs ok to disagree or clarify what needs to be done rather than avoiding a task by making vague promises.

content.quote: For example, if your coworker says:                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                             "Can you automate this process?"

You can say:                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                             "I‚Äôd love to but I don‚Äôt really know how I would go about it. Do you have any ideas by any chance?"

content.text: 7. It‚Äôs impossible / This can‚Äôt be done / We can‚Äôt do that
Emotionally intelligent people are never too quick to shut down ideas or possibilities because they understand the importance of fostering an innovative and forward-thinking work culture.
Instead, they are likely to say:

content.quote: ‚ÄúHow about we push this task to the back burner for now?‚Äù or ‚ÄúThis will be challenging because our team doesn‚Äôt have any prior experience in this area. Can you explain why we would need this? I might be able to dig around and think of a solution.‚Äù

content.text: It‚Äôs important to note that using these phrases doesn‚Äôt necessarily mean you lack emotional intelligence. At the end of the day, as long as you can communicate with politeness and empathy, you will continue to develop your potential and grow your emotional intelligence.
